conclusion: Understanding the problem involves finding work done by gas from state B to C.
State A: pressure \( p_0 \), volume \( v_0 \), temperature \( t_0 \); State C: pressure \( 0.6 p_0 \), volume \( 0.5 v_0 \).
Path from A to B: pressure decreases from \( p_0 \) to \( 0.6 p_0 \) at constant volume \( v_0 \).
Path from B to C: volume decreases from \( v_0 \) to \( 0.5 v_0 \) at constant pressure \( 0.6 p_0 \).
Work done by gas in a constant pressure process is given by \( w = -p \Delta v \).
Calculate work done from B to C: \( w_{b \to c} = 0.3 p_0 v_0 \).
Internal energy \( u \) of ideal gas is related to temperature \( t \) by \( u = a t \).
Ideal gas law: \( p v = n r t \).
From state A to B: Calculate temperature at state B as \( t_1 = 0.6 t_0 \).
From state B to C: Use ideal gas law to relate temperatures and volumes.
